the whole idea is to show the algorithm, not to use built in functions. in job interviews they will ask you to implement sort for example, not to use a built in method..

a small refactor - try to use it without the extra `matrix`  using native 2d array only
ok, will work on that.

thank @nateberkopec, looks like you build a robust framework here. 
i intentionally tried to keep it as simple as i can. 
only methods, no classes, no framework, no extra logistics. the fewer code possible in order to focus on the algorithm alone. 
to me it's the easiest way to quickly understand what it's about. 
i know it's not the 'proper ruby' way but it's the closest i can get from pseudo-code. 
i didn't decide about tests yet because they are always "good practice" but then again since it's a pure algorithm method (that already been tasted and researched) i don't see any real use for them. 
what do you think?

@sagivo You could also just do tests at the bottom of the file - that would be super easy to understand. Something like:

``` ruby
def my_sweet_algo
puts "oh yeah"
end

class TestMySweetAlgo < Test::Unit::TestCase

def test_sweet_algo
  assert true # or whatever
end

end
```

I'm not sure what the settings are off the top of my head, but you can make that test run automatically when you run `ruby my_sweet_algo.rb`.

I think tests could be useful for two reasons:
- When you modify the algorithm, you want to be sure it's still correct. When learning how algorithms work, I'm always modifying the code for a bunch of different reasons.
- When you modify the algorithm, you want to ensure that it's performant. [Minitest has several assertions that help you figure this out](http://madeofcode.com/posts/86-performance-benchmarking-ruby-with-minitest). I think this is very relevant to the purpose of this repo (preparation for interview questions).

unlike tests in 'real world' - algorithm tests are tricker since you can't really test any array to test quicksort for example and see if it runs on o(lgN). it's more just to make sure nothing breaks.

interesting approach. i like the simplicity and the fact that it doesn't take focus from the algorithm itself with extra classes and layers. we can try this with some of the methods.

tl;dr: 
testing to see you dind't break anything while playing is ok, as long as you know it doesn't guarantee your algorithm is correct and most efficient. 
we can keep all the tests in one folder and the algorithms in another as long as we don't build a giant new framework monster (AKA new rails) just to show people a simple way to implement algorithms :)

> algorithm tests are tricker since you can't really test any array to test quicksort for example and see if it runs on o(lgN). it's more just to make sure nothing breaks.

[Actually, minitest/benchmark _does_ do this](http://ruby-doc.org/stdlib-2.0/libdoc/minitest/benchmark/rdoc/MiniTest/Unit/TestCase.html#method-i-assert_performance_power)! It basically runs your code a bunch of times and plots the performance, and checks to see if you pass a statistical regression test.

It's not a formal proof, of course, but I do find it valuable.

> we can keep all the tests in one folder and the algorithms in another as long as we don't build a giant new framework monster (AKA new rails) just to show people a simple way to implement algorithms :)

I actually kind of like the tests-at-the-bottom-of-the-file approach. I'll change this PR to do that instead.

cool, I have removed the rspec tests. will add minitest test for the algo soon. you can merge this one, I will open a new PR once it is ready.

let's keep refactoring. 
- cell does not need these attributes: `column`, `row`. you don't use it anywhere and it depends on the matrix anyway. all cell should have is info if it's live or not so we don't even need this class since it can be a 2d array of bool (the matrix).
- the method `neighbours` should be in the matrix level and should get row and column as parameter.
cool, I can see what you want. I will try to remove the classes and make it more algo centric.
i refactored it. take a look here: https://github.com/sagivo/algorithms/blob/master/lib/binary_search.rb
great. the fewer code the better.
@sagivo  why the previous one not considered? could you explain it please?
it's not a standard binary search. it should return the index of the founded element (or -1 if not). also it's usually better to do it iterative over recursion.

@sagivo Ok. BTW, you always prefer iterative manner rather than recursion? Also could we use a task list. I mean in PM tool with item list that should we will target to implement. Actually i want to more focus on algorithms and populate these stuff in this repository.

since the tests are all the same and look like "check if foo() == value" we can simpy use plain ruby. no need for extra testing library. i prefer to keep it as simple as we can. no need for classes or extra code other than the algorithm itself.

nice catch but `apga` should be 1 since you can do `agpga`.
i refactored it a bit to make it simplier. now it's ok.

@sagivo Hey, please check this out once. I have removed the Cell class and made it much more simpler.
Beautiful. Good job.
can you explain why it's more efficient (space/running time)?

The space required is O(n). I believe in your method you **store the elements** involved in every longest increasing subsequence starting at arr[i]. The first method is kind of storing a matrix. Here the dp array only **stores the length** (single value). The pi array is also used for backtracking. It will also be of length O(n).

The time complexity is still the same. O(n^2)

your algorithm is not correct. it's fundamentally wrong to store only one path since there can be couple paths with better result. 
try:
`p lis_dp [0, 8, 4, 12, 2, 10, 6, 14, 1, 9, 5, 13, 3, 11, 6, 7, 15, 8, 9]`
your algo will return:
`[0, 4, 6, 9, 11]`
while the right answer is (in my solution):
`[0, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]`
please have a look at the wikipedia link to learn more about how to solve it.
Apologies, there's a typho in there. |i,v| should be |v,i|. Let me fix it. The algorithm is correct though. I urge you look for this variant in textbooks.
thanks, please update the readme file as well (with links to relevant info).

can you explain what is it about? 
if it's 2 different algos - put them in separate files. 
also - i would like refactor the whole naming (both methods and variables)

the first is euclidean algorithm to calc gcd.

the extened euclidean algorithm is to calc `a`,`b` s.t `ax+by=gcd(x,y)`, it is often used to calc the modular inverse. for example, if `gcd(x,m)=1`, then the inverse of `x` modular `m` is `a` where `ax+bm=1`. it is also used for solving [linear equation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_equation) or linear congruences.

ok cool. can you update the readme as well?
also - please change the variable names to something else than `aa` and `bb` ..

Ok, I got it. It was clear from your silence on this one while you was working actively on other tickets. 

The whole thing is not about "cross-promotions" since both repos are already promoted enough but about sharing of relevant code base - if I am a developer who is looking for some algorithms - for me it would be good to know that there are additional sources where I can find what I am looking for. I think many developers think about code sharing this way and also pretty lot of projects here at Github contain sections like: "Similar projects", "Alternatives" etc.

I hope this makes sense :)
